suggested_topics: the engineering of ancient Roman aqueducts
how mycelium networks share resources underground
the economics of food trucks in major cities
the role of smell in human memory formation

formats.name: tutorial
formats.instruction: Write a step-by-step guide or how-to for something specific. Number the steps. Include practical details. 200-350 words.

formats.name: numbered_list
formats.instruction: Write a numbered list of 3-5 observations or takes. Each point is 1-2 sentences. No introduction — jump straight into #1.

formats.name: change_my_mind
formats.instruction: State a position you hold and challenge the reader to change your mind. Be genuine — present your reasoning in 2-3 sentences, then invite pushback.

formats.name: does_anyone_else
formats.instruction: Start with 'Does anyone else...' or 'Am I the only one who...' — share a relatable experience or pet peeve in 2-3 sentences.

formats.name: shower_thought
formats.instruction: Write a single surprising observation — ONE sentence only. Do NOT elaborate. Do NOT write an essay. Just the thought.

formats.name: rant
formats.instruction: Go off about something that genuinely annoys you. Be specific and passionate — no measured academic tone. Swear if you want. Keep it to one fiery paragraph.

formats.name: hot_take
formats.instruction: Write a bold, spicy hot take — 2-3 sentences max. Be opinionated and provocative. Do NOT hedge or add caveats.

formats.name: guide
formats.instruction: Write a practical beginner's guide to a topic. Structure with clear sections. Be opinionated about what matters and what doesn't. 250-400 words.

title_styles: Write a declarative, specific title. Examples: 'The real reason bridges fail isn't what you think', 'Three things I changed my mind about this year', 'Sourdough starters are basically version control'
Write a direct, no-nonsense title. Examples: 'X vs Y: which is actually better', 'Stop overcomplicating X', 'A simple framework for thinking about Y'

Write a curious, exploratory title. Examples: 'I went down a rabbit hole on X and here's what I found', 'The weirdest thing about X that nobody talks about', 'X is way more interesting than it sounds'
Write a casual, Reddit-style title. Examples: 'TIL that octopuses have three hearts', 'Does anyone else think X is overrated?', 'I just realized something about Y'
structure_variants: Start with the punchline/conclusion, then explain how you got there.
Write in a single flowing paragraph — no bullet points, no headers, just one continuous thought.
Open with a question, then answer it in your own way.
Write as a stream of consciousness — don't overthink the structure, just let it flow.
